step.value: How does your phone know the word you‚Äôre about to text?
How does Spotify pick the perfect song for you?
How does facial recognition know who you are?
AI has gotten better and better at mimicking the brain. But to understand how AI works, you have to understand human cognition, and recognize the processes we take for granted.
We don't think of the brain as mechanical. Cognition seems to happen in an instant. But it actually requires a series of steps. That‚Äôs a lot like how an algorithm works.
In this interactive, we're slowing down the cognitive process to show you, step by step, how our brains work.

start.byline: Produced and designed by Dan Zedek, research and writing by Jackie Snow, development by Yan Wu

btn.text: How facial recognition knows who you are
How Spotify builds the perfect playlist
How autofill reads your mind when you text or email

text.value: Almost half of your brain is devoted to the visual system ‚Äî and a surprising amount of brainpower is used to identify faces. Facial recognition programs try to recreate that lightning-fast human cognition. It‚Äôs a work in progress.

In a fifth of a second, your brain can decide whether a photo shows a face or some other object. Some neurons in the visual cortex ‚Äî aptly called ‚Äúface cells‚Äù ‚Äî are dedicated solely to faces. They register different features and the spatial relationship between them.

btn.text: What we see in a face

text.value: We‚Äôre exceptionally good at recognizing faces. It takes only a fraction of a second to recognize a loved one or a celebrity.
Can you recognize this face in a flash?

If you guessed Marilyn Monroe, you got it. But it‚Äôs much harder to recognize a face if you take away a feature. That‚Äôs because, to your brain, a face is not a single object, but a combination of features. Most important are the eyes, mouth, and ‚Äî surprisingly ‚Äî eyebrows.
Can you recognize this face without one feature?
Here‚Äôs the same person‚Äôs face, but with no features removed.
Now can you guess who this is?
If you guessed Kim Kardashian, you‚Äôre right. Though she was missing a feature, your brain still knew it was looking at a face.

But when a face is upside down, your face-recognizing cells have trouble. Key landmarks are out of place, so your brain has to draw on other parts of its visual cortex. Upside-down faces confuse AI, too. One computer thought an upside-down image of Kardashian was another celebrity entirely.
Talk about a crazy train! An upside-down photo of Kim Kardashian confused AI so much, it thought it was looking at Ozzy Osbourne.

visual.title: According to AI, who is this?

text.value: Like the brain, facial recognition software identifies features and measures the distance between them. Often, it‚Äôs better than humans. Humans can instantly recognize thousands of faces. AI can recognize millions.
But while the human brain can work around a missing feature, AI has more trouble. A computer saw these images and made its best guess about whom it was seeing.

If AI has this much trouble spotting celebrities, how does it do in real-life situations? So far, not great. Some police departments have piloted facial recognition software and found disturbing results: one program tested by the London metropolitan police made false identifications 80 percent of the time. For now, it still takes humans to guard civil rights.

When you listen to someone speak, your brain makes educated guesses about the words that are coming next. Artificial intelligence uses a similar process to predict the words you‚Äôll text next on your phone.

speech.title: One of these words could save your life

text.value: Early human brains adapted to connect speech with sensory events. Specific neurons in the auditory cortex evolved to respond to different phonemes ‚Äî small units of sound such as ‚Äúf,‚Äù ‚Äút,‚Äù or ‚Äúth‚Äù ‚Äî because anticipating the next word could save precious seconds in life-or-death situations.
So what happens when we type?

In written language, context is still important. AI evaluates the word you‚Äôve typed with your thumbs and suggests different words that could work better. (In this case, it might depend on how you feel about choirs.)
What word comes next?

To predict text, AI also tries to understand the relationships between words. But AI isn‚Äôt hardwired like the brain; it has to learn in a different way. The iPhone and Gmail messaging apps try to guess the next word you‚Äôll type by training on millions of documents and learning the correlations among letters, words, and sentences.

Here‚Äôs a game you can play with your friends: Start a text message with the words ‚ÄúDo you want to meet at 6 for a ‚Äù ‚Äî don‚Äôt forget the space at the end ‚Äî and see what the AI suggests for the next word in the sequence. Depending on your message history, your phone will choose three words that might be different from anyone else‚Äôs.

Sometimes, cultural connotations trump logic, and AI doesn‚Äôt get it. Consider this classic catchphrase from ‚ÄúSaturday Night Live.‚Äù One of these words is the punchline. Three are incorrect answers, suggested by Apple‚Äôs AI. Do you know the right word?

btn.text: Next: When AI gets it wrong

text.value: AI learns by training on human documents, but it can learn human biases ‚Äî requiring human intervention to correct them. Google Translate used to turn the Turkish phrase ‚ÄúO bir doktor‚Äù into ‚ÄúHe is a doctor,‚Äù though ‚Äúo‚Äù is a gender-neutral pronoun. Why? The algorithm saw more examples of doctors identified as men. After a fix, the AI now offers both a ‚Äúhe‚Äù and ‚Äúshe‚Äù translation.

But AI can also help humans function better. People with dyslexia can use AI-assisted tools to make their language expression clearer. The machines learn patterns common to dyslexia in order to predict what people meant to say and substitute the correct words.

One cutting-edge text generator, called GPT-2, can write full paragraphs and stories after getting a short prompt. Some of the text can be a little wonky, but plenty of it reads as if a human wrote it. Some people are concerned the technology could be used to automate trolling or create fake news.

From lullabies to wedding hymns to funeral dirges, music is bound up with emotion. But what makes a song feel right for a moment or mood? Your brain learns, over time, how to pick the perfect song based on your past reactions to music. So does AI.

music.title: Are my sad songs sadder than yours?

text.value: The human brain is hard-wired to make sense of music ‚Äî which is why, though some perceptions of music are cultural, others are universal. Researchers asked members of the Mafa, a Cameroon tribe with no exposure to Western culture, to listen to pop songs. Most of the Mafa correctly labeled the songs happy, sad, or fearful, even without understanding the words.

music.title: If you‚Äôre happy and you know it...

text.value: Drag the slider to show where this music falls on a scale from happiest to saddest.

You might innately sense that a song is happy, but AI has to be taught. Machines measure mood with a metric called ‚Äúvalence.‚Äù The higher the valence, the happier the song. Spotify hires music experts to teach its AI the valence of some songs. That training becomes an algorithm, which the AI then applies to other songs on the platform.
Here‚Äôs how your answers compared to Spotify‚Äôs valence measurements.

music.title: An AI playlist just for you

text.value: To build a playlist for you, Spotify‚Äôs AI compares music you‚Äôve listened to with songs you might not have heard. (It adds extra rules in hard code, like no Christmas music after December 25.) It also looks at a song‚Äôs valence, time signature, key, and ‚Äúdanceability‚Äù ‚Äî a metric based on tempo, rhythm stability, and beat strength.
Where does this music fall on a scale from least to most danceable?
Here‚Äôs how your answers compared to Spotify‚Äôs valence measurements.

slider.text: ‚ÄúMinuet in G Major,‚Äù attributed to J.S. Bach

text.value: Another Spotify metric compares your listening history to those of other users. If you and a friend have similar tastes, perhaps you‚Äôll like her new favorite song. Another tool trawls the internet for text about songs in news articles and blogs. The platform also considers playlists put together by casual listeners and professionals hired by Spotify.
But what if you hate your friend‚Äôs music?

music.title: The right data, the wrong song

text.value: Even with all this data, the Spotify recommendation engine sometimes offers you a song you hate. That‚Äôs because Spotify focuses on technical elements, but doesn‚Äôt know the context ‚Äî a break-up, a bad memory, a pet peeve. Ultimately, taste isn‚Äôt perfectly predictable.

Music occupies special real estate in your brain: Parts of the auditory cortex respond to music-like sounds, but not to speech. That‚Äôs why you might remember song lyrics from decades ago, while forgetting old conversations.

Scientists have found that those special music pathways stay active in patients with dementia. Now, they‚Äôre testing how personalized music programs, like the ones generated by Spotify, can help us communicate with Alzheimer‚Äôs patients.
Explore other ways our brains ‚Äî and AI ‚Äî see the world
